questions.question: Do I need to get a booster?
questions.answer:
Everyone ages 5 years and older should get a COVID-19 booster shot at least 5 months after the completion of their Pfizer and Moderna vaccination series, [according to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/booster-shot.html). For those who received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, it's recommended to get a booster dose of either Pfizer or Moderna (mRNA COVID-19 vaccines) at least 2 months after your shot.

Getting boosted reduces the likelihood of infection and especially of serious illness as vaccination’s [protection against COVID decreases over time](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/acip/meetings/downloads/slides-2021-11-19/06-COVID-Oliver-508.pdf), especially with the rise in new variants.

questions.question: How can you get a vaccine or booster for yourself or someone you care about?
questions.answer:
When you or someone you care about becomes eligible, you can schedule an appointment online or over the phone. There are two primary ways you can find a vaccine appointment:

1. [Vaccines.gov](https://www.vaccines.gov/search/) is a federally supported website managed in partnership with the CDC. It allows individuals to see where vaccines are in stock near their selected zip code, and it provides the phone number, website link, and directions to these sites. Vaccines.gov does not show every vaccine location in every state; it generally focuses on federally enrolled vaccine distributors such as pharmacies. In most cases, Vaccines.gov is easier to navigate than websites run by state governments.
2. [Your state department of health website](https://www.cdc.gov/publichealthgateway/healthdirectories/healthdepartments.html) will provide more comprehensive information about where and how you can get vaccinated in your state. These websites often highlight state-run vaccination sites, such as converted stadiums or convention centers. They also will likely provide more information on how to get vaccinated at locally-run sites, such as hospitals.
3. Your local pharmacy and doctor, pharmacist, or community health center may allow walk-ins or have appointments for vaccines.

questions.question: What is a bivalent COVID booster?
questions.answer: The bivalent booster is an updated COVID booster, developed using a component of the original virus strain and of more recent Omicron variant strains. By using both strains, the bivalent booster offers [additional protection](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7148e1.htm) to previous vaccines. Even those who are fully vaccinated and boosted with the original booster should consider getting the bivalent booster for maximized protection. [Stay up to date with resources from the CDC.](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/stay-up-to-date.html?s_cid=10505:find%20covid%20booster:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21)

questions.question: When can children get the COVID vaccine?
questions.answer:
The [FDA has officially authorized use](https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/coronavirus-covid-19-update-fda-authorizes-moderna-and-pfizer-biontech-covid-19-vaccines-children) of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines for children 6 months and older. This does not include booster shots, which are currently [approved for those 5 and older](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/booster-shot.html#when-you-can-get-booster).

The CDC updates their [recommendations](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/children-teens.html) as new age groups become eligible.

questions.question: Why should children get vaccinated?
questions.answer:
It's important for children to get the COVID vaccine to protect themselves and others. While evidence shows that symptoms of COVID are generally milder in children, they can still get infected and in some cases experience severe symptoms requiring hospitalization. Children can also spread COVID, which puts family and friends at risk. 

The [CDC closely monitors](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/safety-of-vaccines.html) COVID vaccination safety, and recommends that children 6 months or older get vaccinated.

questions.question: Are COVID vaccines safe?
questions.answer:
Yes. While approved COVID vaccines were developed in record time, this does not mean that any safety protocols were bypassed. All vaccines have gone through rigorous testing to ensure their safety. Each vaccine underwent clinical trials where study participants were followed for two months after completing a vaccination series to ensure that the vaccine was safe and effective, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinichealthsystem.org/hometown-health/featured-topic/covid-19-vaccine-myths-debunked). After clinical trials, the Food and Drug Administration reviewed the data and approved the vaccine for public use. Additionally, the Advisory Committee on Immunization carefully reviews all available data before making a recommendation to the CDC.

Even after a vaccine is in use, the CDC continues to [monitor its safety](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/adverse-events.html). For instance, the CDC and FDA thoroughly examined the very rare instance of blood clots in people who received the J&J vaccine. Ultimately, the FDA and CDC determined that the benefits of the J&J vaccine far outweigh its risks and recommended the continued use of this vaccine with monitoring. Informed by this continued monitoring, the CDC more recently [declared a preference for Pfizer and Moderna](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/janssen.html#When-to-Consider-J&J) vaccines over the J&J vaccine, and encourage individuals to discuss concerns with their doctor.

As vaccines are distributed, health care providers will continue to monitor and report adverse reactions to all vaccines through a [national warning system](https://vaers.hhs.gov/about.html). Fortunately, of the millions of people vaccinated so far in the U.S., the vast majority have had only mild side effects if any at all.

questions.question: What are the side effects of the vaccine?
questions.answer:
Not everyone experiences side effects, but if you do, it is generally a sign that your body is building protection. While side effects may get in the way of your daily activities, they typically go away in a few days. According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/expect/after.html), side effects may include: 

* **Pain and swelling on your arm** **where you received the shot**. This can be alleviated by applying a clean, cool, wet washcloth over the area, or by using or exercising your arm. 
* **Fever, chills, tiredness, and headache**. To reduce discomfort from fever, drink plenty of fluids and dress lightly. You may also want to talk to your doctor about taking an over-the-counter medicine, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen. 

You may want to contact your doctor or healthcare provider if: 

* The area around your shot becomes more red and tender after 24 hours.
* Your side effects last longer than a few days or you feel concerned.

questions.question: What should you do with your COVID vaccine card?
questions.answer:
Keeping your COVID vaccine card safe is important. The card is not a legal document but rather a personal record of your medical care. It will most likely be safest if you keep it with your passport or other important papers. As with other personal documents, you should protect your privacy and avoid identity theft by not posting copies or photos (such as a selfie) of your card online in a manner that permits it to be read by others.

* If you’re getting a two-shot vaccine, your vaccine card will note when you are due to get your second shot. It is  important to have it when you show up for your second appointment or booster shot.
* You should take a picture of it, make hard copies, or produce a PDF or similar file by scanning it for your own records. Laminating the original card is not recommended, since it would make it difficult to add additional information to the card, such as your booster confirmation.
* If you've lost your card, without having a backup, you can be re-issued a new card at the place where you got your first shot. You should not let a lost vaccine card deter you from getting your necessary shots.

questions.question: Is it safe to get a COVID vaccine if you are pregnant or breastfeeding?
questions.answer:
According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/pregnancy.html), pregnant people can receive a COVID vaccine. [A recent study](https://www.nejm.org/doi/10.1056/NEJMoa2104983) of over 35,000 pregnant individuals who received the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines found that the shots were not associated with increased risk of pregnancy-related or neonatal adverse events. 

A number of women became [pregnant during vaccine clinical trials](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_wHIYX-tGkGBPwuax7N8BxZPR4PTTCDm/view) and went on to have healthy pregnancies, another good indicator of the safety of the vaccines for this population. In general, inactivated or killed virus vaccines are considered safe to use in pregnancy. For instance, every year pregnant people are able to get a new flu vaccine which is a vaccine that uses a killed version of the flu virus to help the body build natural immunity. This may provide guidance in how to think about COVID vaccine boosters should they become necessary. 

There's also [evidence that antibodies present in breast milk can be transferred](https://www.ajog.org/article/S0002-9378(21)00187-3/fulltext) to infants for added protection for the baby. However, as with other vaccines, the CDC recommends that pregnant and breastfeeding women consult their doctor with any questions about their health history and risk factors.

questions.question: Should you get vaccinated if you are currently infected with or have recovered from COVID?
questions.answer: You should still get vaccinated even if you’ve had COVID, but only after you’ve recovered and met the [criteria](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html) for ceasing to quarantine, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html). While getting COVID may provide you with some natural immunity, it’s not clear how long this protection may last, says the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/coronavirus/in-depth/coronavirus-vaccine/art-20484859#:~:text=Getting%20COVID%2D19%20might,COVID%2D19%20vaccine.). It is  possible to get reinfected with COVID after recovery, which is why vaccination is still important.

questions.question: What can you do after you are vaccinated?
questions.answer:
While recent vaccination doesn’t eliminate all risk of COVID infection, there are activities that you can more safely resume if you’ve been vaccinated and/or boosted within the last 5 months.The protection from two doses of the Moderna or Pfizer vaccine and a single dose of J&J  begins to wane over time and can decrease with the emergence of new, more transmissible  variants. It is recommended to get boosted at least 5 months after completing your primary vaccination series of Pfizer and Moderna, and 2 months after your J&J dose.  The activities that you can safely resume post-vaccination include visiting friends and family and not wearing a mask or practicing social distancing unless it is required by law or specific regulation. Local businesses and workplaces may continue to require masks and social distancing at their discretion.

If you are in a location with a high number of new COVID cases, wearing a mask in public will help you stay safe. If you are exposed to COVID, it's important to increase precautions, such as mask wearing around others, for 10 days. Regardless of symptoms, it's recommended to get tested 5 days after exposure to confirm whether you should continue to wear a mask and social distance for the remaining 5 days (if negative) or isolate (if positive).  

There is currently limited data on how protective vaccines are for immunocompromised people, so the [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/recommendations/immuno.html) that anyone who is immunocompromised should consult their health care provider about these guidelines.

questions.question: Who pays for vaccination?
questions.answer: Under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, a COVID vaccine must be free of charge to anyone who wants it. The federal government has purchased millions of vaccine shots and distributed them to providers. While providers may charge a fee for administering the vaccine, both private insurance and public programs must cover 100 percent of the fee, according to the [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/issue-brief/vaccine-coverage-pricing-and-reimbursement-in-the-u-s/). Uninsured patients also face no charges, as providers are reimbursed for administrative costs by the [Provider Relief Fund](https://www.hrsa.gov/coronavirus), which was established under the CARES Act.

questions.question: What are the ingredients of the vaccines?
questions.answer:
According to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/faq.html), the three COVID vaccines currently available in the United States do not contain eggs, preservatives, or latex. For a full list of ingredients, please see each vaccine’s fact sheet:

* [Pfizer-BioNTech COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144414/download)
* [Moderna COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/144638/download)
* [Johnson & Johnson/Janssen COVID vaccine](https://www.fda.gov/media/146305/download)

questions.question: Will vaccination for COVID cause you to test positive for COVID?
questions.answer:
Receiving a COVID vaccine will not cause you to test positive for COVID. The mRNA vaccines, like Pfizer and Moderna, give instructions for your cells to make a piece of the spike protein, not the entire viral genome. The vaccines simply do not have enough RNA or even the complete RNA sequence to give a positive signal in testing. Similarly, the Johnson & Johnson vaccine — which takes a piece of DNA from the COVID spike protein and combines it with an [adenovirus to carry instructions](https://www.covidactnow.org/covid-explained/roundup-current-vaccine-progress) to your immune system — cannot cause you to test positive for COVID.

If you receive a positive test result in the days or weeks after you have been vaccinated, it is likely because it takes time for the vaccines to work and protection is not 100 percent effective. Anyone who becomes infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus should isolate as recommended.

After vaccination, people may attempt to get a [serology, or antibody, test](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#serology-test) to see if the vaccine has “worked.” However, serology tests focus on a wide set of antibodies, and the vaccine stimulates your immune system to produce antibodies only against the spike protein. So, in order to determine if vaccination has stimulated antibody production, we would need a test that specifically looks for antibodies to the spike protein.

questions.question: I am vaccinated and infected. What should I do?
questions.answer:
While vaccines provide important protection against infection, it is still possible to get infected with COVID. If you’ve tested positive with an at-home rapid test, you can use a lab based test to confirm the results. After confirming your infection and informing those around you who may have been exposed, you should isolate yourself from others. 

There are currently conflicting recommendations on the required length of isolation, but isolating for 10 days after a positive test result is the surest way to avoid infecting others. A secondary round of testing on day 5 of the isolation period can help you confirm whether you still need to isolate the remaining 5 days of the 10 day period. Once you hit day 10, it should definitely be safe for you to end your isolation.

questions.question: Do the COVID vaccines protect against new variants?
questions.answer:
Early research suggests that the COVID vaccines currently available in the U.S. offer adequate protection against new [SARS-CoV-2](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#sars-cov-2) variants. In particular, they have been effective against one of the [most common variants](https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions) known as B.1.1.7/alpha (first identified in the U.K.) and B.1.617.2/delta (first identified in India). 

Emerging research shows that this protection is significantly lower for the Omicron variant, especially for those who received the J&J vaccine. Getting a booster shot [will help strengthen protection](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e3.htm?s_cid=mm7104e3_x) especially against severe illness and death. Reducing the spread of the virus limits its ability to mutate into new variants.

questions.question: Can undocumented immigrants get a free COVID vaccine without legal risk?
questions.answer:
Proof of citizenship, residence or immigration status [is not required to be vaccinated in the U.S.](https://www.dhs.gov/news/2021/02/01/dhs-statement-equal-access-covid-19-vaccines-and-vaccine-distribution-sites) Vaccine sites should not request your social security number, and you can’t be denied vaccination access if you do not provide this type of documentation.

In order to sign up for a vaccine, you will likely be asked demographic, occupational, or health information, as well as need to show some form of ID. This information is important data for public health purposes, and will not be used for immigration enforcement. 

As vaccine requirements vary state to state, it's important to visit [your state’s public health department website](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/php/hd-search/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fphp%2Fopen-america%2Fhd-search%2Findex.html) to check out local vaccine signup requirements.

questions.question: Which COVID vaccine should you get?
questions.answer:
All three COVID vaccines available in the U.S. — Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Johnson and Johnson — are safe and effective. They may have mild side effects, but the benefits far outweigh the risks. The CDC currently [recommends Moderna and Pfizer](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/different-vaccines/janssen.html#When-to-Consider-J&J) over the J&J vaccine, which are generally more protective and have fewer rare adverse effects.

The FDA has officially authorized use of the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines for children 6 months and older. This does not include booster shots, which are currently approved for those 5 years and older.

questions.question: Can you get COVID even after being vaccinated?
questions.answer: It’s [possible](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/health-departments/breakthrough-cases.html), especially with the rise of new variants. However, the risk of infection, and particularly of severe illness or death, is dramatically lower after vaccination and [booster shots](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7104e3.htm?s_cid=mm7104e3_x). Cases of COVID that appear in fully vaccinated people are expected, according to the CDC, as no vaccine currently on the market is 100 percent effective in preventing all infections.

questions.question: Can you transmit COVID after vaccination?
questions.answer: While vaccinated individuals are less likely to acquire or transmit COVID to others, and recent recipients of a booster shot even less so, breakthrough infections do occur especially from more transmissible variants. For this reason, public health officials recommend that vaccinated individuals who have had a known exposure to someone with suspected or confirmed COVID get tested and wear a mask until they have a negative test result. Additionally, the [CDC advises](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/about-face-coverings.html) vaccinated individuals to wear a mask in public indoor settings in areas of substantial or high transmission.

questions.question: Will the COVID vaccines affect fertility?
questions.answer: There is no evidence that any of the COVID vaccines affect fertility, according to the [American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the American Society for Reproductive Medicine, and the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine](https://www.acog.org/news/news-releases/2021/02/medical-experts-assert-covid-vaccines-do-not-impact-fertility).During clinical trials of the COVID vaccines, an equal number of pregnancies occurred in vaccinated and non-vaccinated groups, indicating that the vaccines do not interfere with fertility, according to [reports](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_wHIYX-tGkGBPwuax7N8BxZPR4PTTCDm/view) compiled by a reproductive immunologist with Imperial College London.

questions.question: Should you get the second dose if you had an allergic reaction to the first?
questions.answer: No. If you had a severe allergic reaction to your first shot — one requiring hospital care or treatment with epinephrine — you should not get a second shot of the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccine, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/safety/allergic-reaction.html). Even if you had a mild allergic reaction (hives, swelling, or wheezing) within four hours of your first shot, you should not have a second shot. However, if your reaction to your first dose was limited to an itchy, or red, rash around the injection site, you should still get a second shot. For those with general allergy concerns, you may wish to review the [vaccine ingredients](https://covidactnow.org/faq#what-are-ingredients-vaccine).

questions.question: Will a COVID vaccine change your DNA?
questions.answer: No, the vaccines do not interact with your DNA in any way, according to the [Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/mrna-vaccines-immunity/vid-20507649). The vaccines deliver instructions to your cells to start building protection against the virus that causes COVID, but those instructions don’t become part of your DNA.

questions.question: How is the coronavirus transmitted?
questions.answer:
Evidence suggests that COVID spreads mainly from person to person, primarily through respiratory droplets that are released when a person sneezes, coughs, or talks. These droplets can fall quickly or remain in the air for hours. There are three possible ways people become exposed to them, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/science-briefs/sars-cov-2-transmission.html):

* By inhaling fine particles of virus
* Through deposits of larger particles that reach one’s eyes, nose or mouth
* By touching surfaces contaminated by the virus and then immediately touching your eyes, nose or mouth

Transmission is greatly diminished by good ventilation, maintaining six-feet of physical distance from the source, and reduced exposure time.

questions.question: Does COVID live on surfaces?
questions.answer: The [virus](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#virus) can live from several hours to several days on surfaces, depending on the type of material (cardboard, plastic, etc.). Even so, [the CDC says](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/more/science-and-research/surface-transmission.html) that COVID is not transmitted easily through surfaces and spreads mainly from person-to-person, through exposure to respiratory droplets carrying COVID.

questions.question: Who is most at risk of getting COVID?
questions.answer: Anyone who has been [exposed](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#exposed) to COVID is at risk of contracting the disease, and people of all ages have experienced hospitalization and death. Those who have completed their vaccination series and gotten booster shots have considerably stronger protection against getting COVID and experiencing serious disease. Some people, however, are at greater risk. Elderly individuals, particularly those 85 or older, and people with certain [underlying medical conditions are at higher risk](/glossary#comorbidity) of serious illness, according to the CDC. (Read more about people at increased risk of contracting COVID [at the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fcoronavirus%2F2019-ncov%2Fneed-extra-precautions%2Fpeople-at-increased-risk.html).)

questions.question: Which racial and ethnic minorities are at higher risk of contracting COVID and becoming seriously ill?
questions.answer:
Data from the CDC shows that race and ethnicity, similar to age, impact an individual’s vulnerability to COVID. The rates of COVID cases, hospitalizations and deaths among Blacks, Hispanic and Latino persons, and American Indians and Native Alaskans are much higher than that of white people, according to the CDC’s calculation of [COVID-19 Hospitalization and Death by Race/Ethnicity](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/investigations-discovery/hospitalization-death-by-race-ethnicity.html).

According to COVID vulnerability data, U.S. residents living in the most vulnerable communities have been more likely to be diagnosed with COVID, significantly more likely to have died from COVID, and less likely to have been tested for COVID. A number of social factors contribute to COVID vulnerability for racial and ethnic minorities. For example, minorities tend to have [higher rates of poverty](https://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/poverty-rate-by-raceethnicity/?currentTimeframe=0&sortModel=%7B%22colId%22:%22Location%22,%22sort%22:%22asc%22%7D), according to data from the Kaiser Family Foundation, and [less access to health care](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/health-equity/race-ethnicity.html). This puts them at greater risk of underlying medical conditions that result in more severe COVID cases. [The CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/health-equity/race-ethnicity.html) reports that racial and ethnic minorities are also more likely to be essential workers, live in multi-generational housing, and have less ability to take time off from work when sick or to work from home. Discrimination, including racism, contributes to long-term social deficits and more immediately to inadequate health care access, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/health-equity/race-ethnicity.html). Learn more about vulnerability data and why it matters [in our explainer](https://covidactnow.org/covid-explained/covid-vulnerability-data).

questions.question: What are the symptoms of COVID?
questions.answer: Symptoms of COVID vary widely between different people. The most common symptoms include fatigue, cough and fever. Loss of smell or taste is also a frequent, early symptom. Other symptoms that people with COVID may experience include shortness of breath, muscle or body ache, sore throat, chills, congestion, headache, stomach pain (including nausea and diarrhea), pink eye (conjunctivitis) and chest pain. COVID symptoms generally appear two to 14 days after exposure. For more information on symptoms and when to seek medical help, [go to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html).

questions.question: How common is it to have COVID but not have any symptoms?
questions.answer: Many individuals infected with COVID are [asymptomatic](/glossary#asymptomatic) (that is, they do not have symptoms of the virus). When people do not know that they are ill, they do not take precautions. In much the same way, people who are “[presymptomatic](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#presymptomatic-spread)” – that is, they will eventually develop symptoms ‒ may unknowingly spread the disease to others before they realize that they are ill. The [CDC estimates](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/hcp/planning-scenarios.html) that around 30 percent of COVID cases are asymptomatic.

questions.question: Are children at risk of becoming sick with COVID?
questions.answer: Children can become infected and sick with COVID. [According to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/faq.html#Children), fewer children get sick than adults and most display mild symptoms or are [asymptomatic](/glossary#asymptomatic). However, children with underlying medical conditions or infants (less than 1 year old) may be at increased risk for severe illness. There have also been cases of a rare disease called [multisystem inflammatory syndrome (MIS-C)](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/children/mis-c.html), which has been linked to COVID.

questions.question: How long are you contagious with COVID?
questions.answer: [According to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/end-home-isolation.html), a person with COVID is most likely no longer contagious when at least 10 days have passed since symptom onset or your first positive test, regardless of whether you are up to date on vaccination. You can ensure that you are no longer contagious with COVID after 10 days by receiving a negative test result.  The [CDC has updated their recommended isolation period](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/quarantine-isolation.html) to five days, based on studies that have shown that the majority of transmissions take place early in the illness. However, if possible, you should isolate for the full 10 day period or until you receive a negative test result. If you must leave isolation before the 10 day period and without a negative test result, it is recommended that you operate as if you may be an active infection risk to others by wearing a mask and practicing social distancing.

questions.question: Can you get COVID more than once?
questions.answer: While [antibodies](/glossary#antibodies) from infection may offer some protection against the virus, there is no evidence to suggest that people are immune to COVID after their first infection. Vaccination and booster doses provide stronger protection against reinfection than natural immunity, but it is still possible to get infected with COVID, especially with the rise of new variants. The current understanding of reinfection is limited due to the novelty of the virus, but ongoing studies will provide more insight into how frequently reinfection occurs and how long immunity from COVID may last after your first infection. Even if you’ve already had COVID or have antibodies, the [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/reinfection.html#:~:text=Cases%20of%20reinfection%20with%20COVID,some%20reinfections%20are%20expected.) taking the same precautions against the virus, including  [vaccination](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/index.html), [mask wearing](/glossary#face-mask) and [social distancing](/glossary#social-distancing) when necessary.

questions.question: What are the long-term effects of COVID?
questions.answer: Most people who have COVID recover relatively quickly, within several weeks. However, some do not. One [study](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41591-021-01292-y) of approximately 4,000 COVID patients found that about 20 percent had symptoms lasting for more than 28 days to more than 12 weeks. Research is ongoing about why certain individuals experience [post-COVID conditions](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/long-term-effects.html), or “long COVID.” Long-lasting symptoms vary in severity, but most commonly include fatigue, headaches, and difficulty breathing.

questions.question: What is counted as a COVID death?
questions.answer:
The [WHO](https://www.who.int/classifications/icd/Guidelines_Cause_of_Death_COVID-19.pdf?ua=1) states that a COVID death can be “a death resulting from a clinically compatible illness, in a probable or confirmed COVID-19 case, unless there is a clear alternative cause of death that cannot be related to COVID disease (e.g. trauma). There should be no period of complete recovery from COVID-19 between illness and death.” (The CDC’s  offers further [guidance](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/coding-and-reporting.htm) on reporting and coding deaths due to COVID.)

Tracking the number of COVID deaths is difficult, and some suggest that the number is underreported. One issue is that individuals infected with the [virus](/glossary#virus) may be sick for many days, or even weeks, before death, so the increase in deaths resulting from a [wave](/glossary#wave) of [infections](/glossary#infection) may lag significantly in time. In some cases people may die indirectly from COVID, because hospitals were overcrowded with COVID patients and care was late or unavailable. To track the number of COVID deaths, researchers rely on something called “excess mortality” — the number of deaths from all causes during a crisis that are above the historical average during non-crisis times. For information on excess mortality, see the CDC’s report, [Excess Deaths Associated with COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/excess_deaths.htm).

questions.question: Why was bivalent booster data added to your site in January 2023?
questions.answer:
The bivalent booster protects against both original COVID strains and newer Omicron variants. It provides important additional protection, and helps to address the waning effectiveness of the original vaccine over time.  

In our ongoing effort to provide the most relevant and up to date COVID data, we shifted our focus towards the CDC’s updated booster data and de-emphasized 1+ and 2+ vaccine dose data. By tracking and presenting the percentage of state, county, and metro residents who have received a dose of any of the bivalent COVID boosters, we aim to help our users understand how different communities across the country are continuing to protect themselves from COVID. 

[Read more to learn about what a “bivalent booster” is](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/How-Do-I-Get-a-COVID-19-Vaccine.html?s_cid=10505:find%20covid%20booster:sem.ga:p:RG:GM:gen:PTN:FY21) and why boosters are important for additional protection against COVID.

questions.question: Why were changes made to your site in April 2022?
questions.answer:
We at CAN care deeply about our users and our objective is to provide users with the most accurate, accessible, and actionable COVID data available. We have continued to update our site and framework accordingly over the past two years. 

The CDC recently updated their COVID framework to capture what they call “COVID-19 Community Levels.” These changes reflect the now decreased risk of severe illness and death from COVID due to vaccines, therapeutics, and past COVID infections, as well as other developments. This new CDC framework and its recommendations account for all of this, and prioritize reducing severe illness and death and preventing healthcare systems from being overwhelmed. Its aim is to help communities across the country live safely with the coronavirus, while also, as much as possible, returning to some version of normal life.

We are not afraid to diverge from the CDC and other frameworks, and have done so repeatedly in the past. Our objective is to provide our users with the most accurate, accessible, and actionable COVID data available. Fortunately, after evaluating the CDC’s latest framework independently and carefully with our Medical Board of Advisors, we believe it better reflects the latest state of the pandemic and have decided to align our products with it.

questions.question: Where are the previous highlighted metrics like Daily New Cases, Infection Growth Rate, Hospitalizations, and Deaths?
questions.answer:
We remain committed to continuing to make all of our previous metrics available on our site and in our API. 

We acknowledge that people who need extra caution may still want to make decisions using our older metrics, which now fall under the category of **Transmission levels**. Daily new cases, infection rate, and positive test rate can all still be found on location pages within the "Transmission metrics" component, as well as within "All metrics," also known as the "Trends" component. 

Additional hospitalization metrics and deaths can also be found within "All metrics," or the "Trends" component.

questions.question: What are health service areas?
questions.answer:
Health Service Areas (HSAs) are defined by the CDC to be a single county or a cluster of adjacent counties which are relatively self-contained with respect to hospital care. 

The CDC bases its [Community Level Framework](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/community-levels.html) on a set of hospital health metrics that are measured at the Health Service Area-level so that counties without significant hospital resources are still assigned a meaningful Community Level.  As such, the hospital metrics on our county location pages are often calculated at the HSA-level.  This means that a county with no (or few) hospitals may still show a non-trivial number of hospital admissions or ICU beds used, etc.

questions.question: Why is infection rate important?
questions.answer:
Infection rate, also known as R(t) or “R-effective,” is important because it estimates how fast COVID is spreading right now.

To give an example, if the R(t) is 3, it indicates that one infected person will most likely infect three other people, and those three people will each go on to infect three more people. We as a community can change it by modifying community behavior (whether there are large gatherings) and intervention practices (whether people wear masks and maintain social distancing).

![infection rate diagram shows how many people one person would go on to infect if RT is 3.](/images_cms/infection-rate-diagram.png "COVID spread if infection rate is 3")

questions.question: What is R-naught (R₀) and how is it different from R(t)?
questions.answer: R-naught (R₀), represents the natural ability of a virus to spread in an unprotected population where no special precautions are being taken. [R(t)](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#rt), in contrast, takes into account public health measures or the development of a [vaccine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#vaccine). This makes R(t) —the actual or “effective” of the virus under current conditions — a more accurate reflection of the number of people that a single infected person is expected to infect in a specific area at a specific time. It is also more relevant than R₀ in directing public policy and informing private behavior. The value of R(t) can change over time, depending on such factors as how many people are staying home or wearing masks. At Covid Act Now, we look at R(t), or [infection rate](https://covidactnow.org/covid-community-level-metrics#infection-rate), because it represents more closely what is happening right now and is calculated based on actual case data.

questions.question: Why is testing important?
questions.answer: Testing is essential to help slow COVID spread by allowing health officials to identify and isolate infected individuals, and begin [contact tracing](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#contact-tracing) to [quarantine](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#quarantine) people who were exposed. It is also an important indicator of how much COVID is in a community, and when it may be safe to resume ordinary activities. To learn more about what COVID tests are available and when to get tested, see the [CDC’s testing guidelines](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/testing.html).

questions.question: What does positive test rate tell us?
questions.answer:
Positive test rate, also known as test positivity, is a good indicator of how widespread testing is in a given area. If a state or county has a *high* positive test rate, it is a sign of insufficient testing in that area. If a state or county has a *low* positive test rate, it is a sign that we are testing more than only the sickest people. Testing a larger number of at-risk populations (essential workers, people notified via contact tracing , etc.) is key to catching unknown infections before they can lead to an outbreak.

Let’s look at the pictures below. **There are two positive COVID tests in each of these scenarios, but the positive test rate differs drastically due to the percentage of the population that is being tested.** The closer we get to testing everyone, the less likely we are to miss positive cases.

![key for images](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-key.jpg "key for images")

![scenario of insufficient testing with positive test rate of 20 percent, where only 10 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-high.jpg "Insufficient testing scenario")

In the first scenario, two out of 10 people test positive for COVID, so the positive test rate is 20 percent. The remaining 90 percent of the population remain untested.

![scenario of bare minimum testing with positive test rate of 10 percent, where only 20 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-medium.jpg "Scenario of bare minimum testing")

In the second scenario, two out of 20 people test positive for COVID, so the positive test rate is 10 percent. The remaining 80 percent of the population remain untested.

![scenario of sufficient testing with positive test rate of 2 percent, where 100 percent of the population is tested. ](/images_cms/test-positivity-calculate-low.jpg "Scenario with sufficient testing")

In the last scenario, two out of 100 people test positive for COVID, so the test positivity is 2 percent. The entire population is tested.

questions.question: Why is ICU capacity used important?
questions.answer: The ICU is the part of a hospital for people who are the sickest. Each ICU bed is staffed by specially trained personnel and supported with special equipment, such as ventilators. They are needed to treat not only COVID patients, but also other patients, such as people who have had a heart attack or suffered a life-threatening injury.

questions.question: How do you travel safely?
questions.answer:
If you are fully vaccinated, [the CDC states](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated-guidance.html#anchor_1617376530945) that you can travel domestically with low risk to yourself, as long as you wear an effective mask. You do not need to get tested before or after domestic travel unless you have COVID-like [symptoms](https://covidactnow.org/faq#what-symptoms-covid). 

Unvaccinated individuals should get a viral test one to three days before travel and again three to five days after travel, [according to the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/travel-during-covid19.html). In addition, they should self-quarantine for a full five days after travel, even if they have a negative test result. 

In addition, all passengers on public transportation, including trains, buses, and planes, must wear masks.

questions.question: How soon after a possible exposure to COVID should you get tested if you are vaccinated or unvaccinated?
questions.answer:
If you are vaccinated, you need to get tested if you are presenting COVID symptoms, have had known contact with someone with suspected or confirmed COVID, or live or work in certain places, such as a correctional detention facility or homeless shelter. 

Unvaccinated people should quarantine for at least five days after any potential exposure to the virus.

Since COVID has a long [incubation period](https://www.covidactnow.org/glossary#incubation-period), it may take a few days before [PCR tests](https://www.covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) detect a sufficient enough amount of the virus to report a positive result. While it’s recommended to [quarantine](https://www.covidactnow.org/glossary#quarantine) for five days, [experts recommend](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/if-you-are-sick/quarantine.html) being tested at least five days after a probable exposure for the most accurate test results.

The [CDC recommends](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/quarantine-isolation.html) that anyone who shows symptoms for COVID, regardless of vaccination status, should get tested.

Rapid tests, also known as [antigen tests](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#antigen-test), and [PCR tests](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#pcr-test) are the two types of diagnostic tests for COVID. Both tests are performed by collecting nasal or throat swabs, but rapid tests report results more swiftly, as all PCR tests require lab processing. While rapid tests are more convenient and often cheaper, they report higher rates of false negatives. PCR tests are most accurate for detecting active infections, while rapid tests are best used to quickly confirm COVID symptoms.
questions.question: Are rapid tests less accurate than PCR tests?
Do masks help stop the spread of COVID?
questions.answer: Yes! [Masks](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) that cover your nose and mouth are extremely helpful in reducing the spread of COVID. They help to protect you and those around you, according to the [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/media/releases/2020/p0714-americans-to-wear-masks.html) and [WHO](https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public/when-and-how-to-use-masks). The virus can spread between people interacting in close proximity, even if no one is exhibiting any [symptoms](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#asymptomatic), and wearing a mask gives you an added layer of protection. While a [growing amount of research](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/science-briefs/fully-vaccinated-people.html) indicates that vaccines and boosters help prevent transmission, there are still [certain circumstances](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated.html) in which vaccinated people need to wear masks.

questions.question: What kind of masks are the most effective?
questions.answer: Wearing a [mask](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#face-mask) is extremely important for both you and those around you to decrease the risk of getting and spreading COVID, especially if you have not been vaccinated. However, not all masks are created equal. [Experts recommend](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/about-face-coverings.html) wearing masks that have two or more layers of breathable fabric, and that fit snugly against the sides of your face, over the bridge of your nose, and below your chin. Cloth masks are effective to some extent, but medical masks, N95 masks, and KN95 masks are the most effective at filtering out particules and keeping you protected, especially against the more transmissive COVID variants. [Make sure the masks](https://www.nytimes.com/article/covid-masks.html?action=click&state=default&region=hub&context=storyline_hub&module=styln-coronavirus&variant=show&pgtype=LegacyCollection) you use are not counterfeits so they will provide proper protection.

questions.question: How do you discuss the pandemic with friends or family members who aren’t taking it seriously?
questions.answer:
It can be challenging to discuss the pandemic with people who think it’s overblown and aren’t taking precautions. You may be tempted to immediately begin reciting the facts and what the data is showing, but sometimes this can put people off. Instead, it’s important to consider how you are presenting those facts. [Research](https://www.mikeyeomans.info/papers/receptiveness.pdf) finds that conversations are more productive when you avoid condescending tones and let the other person know that you are listening. Try these approaches:

* Actively solicit their perspective on the issue, and show that you are listening (e.g., say “I hear you” or “I see what you mean”). When you understand the beliefs of your friends or family members, you can tailor how you communicate with them in a way that resonates with them instead of turning them off. 
* Avoid allowing your emotions to get the best of you. Stay calm and objective, using a friendly tone to share your thoughts. A collected and approachable tone improves the chances of your counterpart listening to the facts and learning from you.

questions.question: What can you do to help end the pandemic and protect yourself from COVID?
questions.answer:
Your actions matter. You can help protect others and slow the spread of the virus by doing a few simple things:

* [Get vaccinated or boosted](https://www.vaccines.gov/) as soon as you can. Everyone 6 months and up is eligible for the vaccine and those 5 years and up are eligible for the booster in the United States.
* [Wear a mask](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/11/health/cdc-revising-vaccination-data.html) when necessary unless there is a medical reason not to do so. If you have had 2 or more shots of Pfizer of Moderna and 1 dose of J&J plus a booster , you should continue to wear a mask and practice social distancing in public, indoor spaces, and large outdoor gatherings when COVID transmission is high or mask wearing is mandated by law. For more details about when you should wear a mask after you are fully vaccinated, visit the [CDC website](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/vaccines/fully-vaccinated-guidance.html).
* Follow recommended limits on in-person gatherings, especially those that take place indoors. Taking a [rapid antigen test](https://covidactnow.org/glossary#antigen-test) directly before you gather with people outside of your immediate household can help identify if you are infected and reduce the spread of the virus. You can [order free at-home rapid tests here](https://www.covidtests.gov/).
